data.source: World Values Survey (WVS) for polarization measures; government consumption (GOVCONS) and transfers/subsidies (GOVTRANSSUB) data (averaged 2003–2005); democracy classification measures (e.g., Political Regime Characteristics and Transitions/Polity).
data.sample_size: Approximately 83 countries; about 1,000 respondents per country (with some exclusions for missing data).
data.notes: Polarization measured primarily as the standard deviation of responses to four WVS economic policy questions (EQUALITY, PRIVATE, GOV, COMP), with robustness checks using Esteban–Ray and bipolarization (share of extreme responses). Polarization measures across questions are highly correlated (0.72–0.81). Some countries excluded due to missing outcomes or response issues; Pakistan had high non-response. Potential measurement error noted in weak democracies.

method.description: Cross-country regression analysis relating survey-based measures of electorate polarization to government size, primarily government consumption as a share of GDP. Polarization is computed from WVS responses to economic policy questions. Analyses are conducted separately for strong and weak democracies and include extensive controls and robustness checks (income inequality, corruption, trust, response rates, party fragmentation, supporter-level polarization, and alternative polarization metrics).
steps: Assemble WVS country-level data on responses to four economic policy questions and compute polarization measures (standard deviation; robustness with Esteban–Ray and bipolarization).
Merge polarization data with country-level government consumption (GOVCONS, averaged 2003–2005) and transfers/subsidies (GOVTRANSSUB).

Classify countries by democratic strength and prepare control variables (e.g., GDP per capita, inequality, ethnic fragmentation, geography, colonial history, demographics, trust in parliament, corruption, turnout, consensus).
Estimate baseline and expanded OLS regressions of government size on polarization with robust standard errors, separately for strong and weak democracies.

Conduct robustness checks: include Gini inequality; derive income-adjusted polarization; control for response rates and ideological coherence; examine party/government fragmentation indices; analyze polarization among government vs opposition supporters; estimate interaction models (e.g., with fragmentation and government seat share).
Report and compare coefficients across specifications (basic, short, long), assess statistical significance, and interpret effect magnitudes.
method.models: Cross-country OLS linear regressions with robust standard errors; interaction models with institutional variables; factor analysis for spending dimensions; alternative polarization constructions.
method.outcome_variable: Government consumption (GOVCONS) as a share of GDP (average 2003–2005); general government transfers and subsidies (GOVTRANSSUB) as a share of GDP.
method.independent_variables: Primary: electorate polarization (SD of WVS responses to EQUALITY, PRIVATE vs GOV ownership, GOV responsibility, and COMP). Robustness: Esteban–Ray polarization; bipolarization (share of extreme responses); polarization among government/opposition supporters; income-adjusted polarization.
method.control_variables: GDP per capita; income inequality (Gini); ethnic/linguistic fragmentation; demographics; geography; colonial history; trade and economic indicators; press freedom; perceived corruption; confidence in parliament; voter turnout; consensus (distance from midpoint); party/government fractionalization (HERFGOV, HERFLEG, NGOV, NLEG, LEGPOL).

results.summary: Electorate polarization is negatively associated with government size in strong democracies and near zero in weak democracies. In strong democracies, a one standard deviation increase in polarization reduces government consumption by roughly 2.0–6.1 percentage points (about 4.0 pp on average). Results are robust to controls (income inequality, corruption, trust, consensus, response rates), alternative polarization measures, and to using transfers/subsidies as the outcome. Evidence suggests polarization influences spending rather than the reverse; party/government fragmentation measures do not consistently mediate the relationship.
